title: Essential Greetings
description: Learn how to greet people in Portuguese with common phrases for different times of day and situations.

vocabulary.notes: Universal greeting, works in all situations
Used after evening and when saying goodbye at night
Formal, implies you won't see the person for a while
Formal way to ask how someone is
Informal, very common in everyday conversation

grammar.title: Formal vs Informal
grammar.content: Portuguese has different levels of formality. Use 'Como está?' with strangers, elderly people, or in professional settings. Use 'Tudo bem?' with friends, family, or people your age.
examples: Formal: Bom dia, senhor. Como está?

grammar.title: Gender Agreement in 'Obrigado'
grammar.content: When saying thank you, men say 'obrigado' and women say 'obrigada'. This is because you're saying 'I am obliged/grateful' and the adjective must match your gender.

exercises.question: What greeting would you use at 3:00 PM?
exercises.explanation: Boa tarde (Good afternoon) is used from noon until evening, around 7 PM.

exercises.question: Which is the informal way to say goodbye?
exercises.explanation: Tchau is the casual, informal way to say bye. Adeus is more formal and implies a longer separation.

exercises.question: How do you say 'Good morning' in Portuguese?
exercises.explanation: Bom dia means 'Good morning' and is used until noon.

exercises.question: If you're a woman saying thank you, which do you say?
exercises.explanation: Women say 'obrigada' because the word is an adjective that must match the speaker's gender.

exercises.question: Complete: Olá! ____ bem?
exercises.explanation: 'Tudo bem?' is a common informal greeting meaning 'Everything good?' or 'How are you?'

culturalNotes.title: The Two-Kiss Greeting
culturalNotes.content: In Portugal, friends and family greet each other with two kisses on the cheek (starting with the right cheek). This is common in casual settings but not in formal business environments.

culturalNotes.title: Using 'Senhor' and 'Senhora'
culturalNotes.content: When addressing someone formally, use 'senhor' (sir/Mr.) or 'senhora' (ma'am/Mrs.) followed by their last name. Example: 'Bom dia, Senhor Silva!'
